Using the songs lyrics to create her own rhythms, she feeds off the beat of a prominent drum line but is never ruled by it.

The title track ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢HyperboreansÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ sees Jackie joined by the trackÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s composer Alasdair Roberts and the ensuing duet perfectly showcases both voices. Compared with the dark stories later on in the album, the track is a breath of fresh air - a burst of childlike innocence before life experience takes over. The instrumentation echoes this, a light accompaniment providing support for the dual voices whenever necessary. The repeated phrases within the instrumental section evoke memories of nursery rhymes sung at bed time - alongside tales of Utopian societies where the Hyperboreans might live.

Childhood innocence is soon lost with the following track. If ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢Past CaringÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ offers a moment of aural respite, then ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢May the KindnessÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ is the equivalent of a snugly jumper and warming fire on a cold winters day. Over the top JackieÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s voice floats, at times sounding as clear as if she were in the room, truly stunning and the perfect end to an incredible album.

Produced by her brother, Jim Moray it also features a host of talented musicians. With 11 lovingly crafted tracks, all bringing out different qualities in her utterly beguiling voice, it does not disappoint at all.
